docs.lead_paragraph: Santa Artiles says that her most fervent wish is that a cure will be found in time to save her 5-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter from the rare blistering disease that is torturing them as it is killing them. But she also knows that such a development is not likely, so her second-strongest wish is that ''I make their time joyful for whatever time they have left.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; A Mother Trying to Put Some Joy in What Remains of Her 2 Children's Lives

docs.snippet: Santa Artiles says that her most fervent wish is that a cure will be found in time to save her 5-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter from the rare blistering disease that is torturing them as it is killing them.     But she also knows that such a...

docs.lead_paragraph: SAMANTHA BEE was nudging her feet into a pair of black boots at the Fluevog store in SoHo, just a replacement pair for her old ones, which seemed no longer to meet the standards of a rising TV personality. Make that a rising pregnant TV personality. Unlike the star of ''Alias,'' Jennifer Garner, who is also pregnant, Ms. Bee, the only on-camera female correspondent on Comedy Central's ''Daily Show With Jon Stewart,'' does all her own stunts. But Ms. Bee's stunts are generally verbal, like the time she asked a man leaving a voting booth not which candidate he chose but had he ''ever had a homosexual thought?'' Ms. Bee's path to one of the hottest shows on television was surprisingly ordinary. She wasn't a celebrity in Canada and had no connections. ''I auditioned, then I had a callback, then I got the job, then I moved to New York,'' she said. ''It's not like they came to Canada to see me. They overturned a bunch of rocks and I happened to be sitting under one.''

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Samantha Bee; Joking for Two
headline.kicker: A Night Out With | Samantha Bee

docs.snippet: Samantha Bee's old boots seemed no longer to meet the standards of a rising TV personality. Make that a rising pregnant TV personality.

docs.lead_paragraph: Used correctly, latex condoms greatly reduce the risks of pregnancy and disease, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday in a 63-page report. Prepared in response to a five-year-old law, the report is to form the basis for labels for condom packaging and provide more up-to-date information about effectiveness.

headline.main: F.D.A. Reports Reduced Risks With Condoms

docs.abstract: FDA report, to be used on package labels, says condoms used correctly greatly reduce risks of pregnancy and several sexually-transmitted diseases including HIV; Sen Tom Coburn, who sponsored legislation that produced report, says 'misleading' recommendations put public at risk; he and Repr Mark Souder say FDA overstates protection against disease and cervical cancer (S)
docs.snippet: Used correctly, latex condoms greatly reduce the risks of pregnancy and disease, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday in a 63-page report.      Prepared in response to a five-year-old law, the report is to form the basis for labels for...

docs.lead_paragraph: New tests in the first trimester of pregnancy are better at identifying fetuses with Down syndrome than standard tests done later in pregnancy, according to a government-financed study. The first-trimester tests detected as many as 87 percent of fetuses with the extra chromosome that causes Down syndrome, compared with 81 percent found by tests in the second trimester, the authors write in today's issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: New, Earlier Tests Seen Better at Fetal Down Syndrome Detection

docs.snippet: New tests in the first trimester of pregnancy are better at identifying fetuses with Down syndrome than standard tests done later in pregnancy, according to a government-financed study.

docs.lead_paragraph: For generations of adults who prize old television shows from their past, the madeleines of youth were mostly Twinkies. Even though the series were jammed with artificial ingredients and gooey centers, there's a nostalgic hunger for any morsels of the television industry's yesteryears, and cable channels are offering a full buffet. TV Land has just presented -- and is rerunning -- its behind-the-scenes series ''TV Land Confidential,'' Bravo is reassembling casts for a batch of reunion specials and VH1 has begun dredging up another decade of memories in ''I Love the 80's 3-D.''
docs.abstract: Ned Martel Critic's Notebook column on proliferation of cable programs about old television shows, including TV Land Confidential, Bravo's reunion specials and VH1's I Love the 80's 3-D; photos (M)
docs.snippet: There's a nostalgic hunger for any morsels of the television industry's yesteryears, and cable channels are offering a full buffet.
